@GenYHomeBuyer But that doesn't mean we shouldn't have the conversations.
@GenYHomeBuyer I think it's harder than people think when they say less migration. The system isn't setup for governments to pick numbers.
@GenYHomeBuyer Yes, I agree. But international student numbers went up as Federal government reduced government funding.
@GenYHomeBuyer 4th. Could reduce permanent migration numbers? But that only accounts for 40% of new migrants and hurts temp-perm movements.
@GenYHomeBuyer 3rd. Backpackers are between 5-15 per cent. They are bilateral agreements. If we cap/limit, what will happen to Oz overseas?
@GenYHomeBuyer Should this be closed and force Kiwis to get visas like everyone else? It would upend 70 years of open access.
@GenYHomeBuyer 2nd. Kiwis have made up about 5-15% of net migrants over last decade because of open border arrangements.
@GenYHomeBuyer But as soon as this occurs, universities don't have incentive to compete for students, changing behaviour of HighEd
@GenYHomeBuyer OK. Students are about 30% of new migrants. Could cap # of students. How would they be divided among unis and TAFEs?
@GenYHomeBuyer Negative gearing, better oversight, more density in inner-city. These are difficult politically but not otherwise.
@GenYHomeBuyer I'd argue reducing migration is complex, has large unknown consequences and difficult to achieve but others would disagree.
